3Bear Energy Libby Gas Plant
3Bear Energy Services
Executive Summary
Risk Management Plan
EPA Identifier:  100000239333


Accidental Release Prevention and Response

The 3Bear Libby Gas Plant is committed to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the facility's processes.  It is the practice of 3Bear Energy Services LLC. to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of substances. However, if a release does occur, trained personnel will respond to, control and contain the release.

3Bear Energy Libby Gas Plant is located in Lea County New Mexico and is owned by 3Bear Energy Services, LLC. operated by 3Bear Field Services, LLC.

The 3Bear Libby Gas Plant is a cryogenic NGL processing facility. The plant inlet is fed by remote compressor stations to move gas from the wellhead into the high pressure lateral to the facility.  The plant is designed to process natural gas and extract the NGL liquid from the product stream.  The inlet gas is separated from the pipeline liquids via the inlet slug catcher.  The pipeline liquids are then heated, the water is separated, and the condensate is routed to the stabilizer tower.  The stabilized liquid is routed to and stored in atmospheric tanks.  Gas from the stabilizer is recompressed in the overhead compressor and combined with the slug catcher gas and routed through a coalescing filter.  The CO2 and H2S is then removed from the gas stream via contact with amine.  The amine is reclaimed in the regeneration system where the acid gas (CO2, H2S) is removed and sent to a thermal oxidizer.  The treated gas stream is then routed through the molecular sieve bed(s) to remove H20.  Once the gas stream has been stripped and dried it is then ran through the cryogenic process, including the JT valve, turbo expander and demethanizer towe

r into NGL product.  Finished products are residual natural gas and extracted hydrocarbon liquids which are removed from the plant by pipeline systems.  The purpose of this Risk Management Plan (RMP) is to provide information about our operations at the facility, our emergency response plans in case an accidental release should occur, our 5-year accident history.  

The3Bear Libby Gas Plant was evaluated to determine if any regulated flammable or toxic substances exceeded the threshold quantity.  3Bear Energy Services identified the regulated substances and quantities kept on site based on process knowledge.

Listed flammable substances which are present above the threshold quantities at the 3Bear Energy Libby Gas Plant are methane, and a mixed hydrocarbon (Y-Grade) product containing ethane, propane, iso-butane, normal butane, iso-pentane and pentane.  The Plant is subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation and is classified as a Program Level 1 site under the EPA RMP program.

Five Year Accident History

The 3Bear Energy Libby Gas Plant began operations on September 2018 and has no history of releases of listed Hazardous Substances which have resulted in onsite or offsite effects.  

Emergency Procedures Information

The 3Bear Energy Libby Gas Plant maintains a written emergency procedure, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The procedures are for the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address notification of local emergency response agencies if a release occurs.  Employees receive training in emergency procedures.  The emergency procedure is updated when necessary based on modifications made to the plant facilities.

In the event of an emergency involving our natural gas liquid extraction facility, it is 3Bear Energy Services policy to follow our Emergency Response Plan.

The overall emergency procedure program for the 3Bear Energy Libby Gas Plant is coordinated with Lea County Emergency Management.  This coordination includes periodic meetings, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials and industry representatives.  The Libby Gas Plant has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate Emergency Management officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  In addition to periodic Emergency Management meetings, the3Bear Energy Libby Gas Plant conducts periodic emergency drills that involve Emergency Management and emergency response organizations.
